metadata.titleEn: 1:100,000 landuse dataset of Inner Mongolia Autonomous Region (2000)
metadata.description: This data was derived from "1: 100,000 Land Use Data of China". Based on Landsat MSS, TM and ETM remote sensing data, 1: 100,000 Land Use Data of China was compiled within three years by a remote sensing scientific and technological team of 19 research institutes affiliated to the Chinese Academy of Sciences, which was organized by the “Remote Sensing Macroinvestigation and Dynamic Research on the National Resources and Environment", one of the major application programs in Chinese Academy of Sciences during the "Eighth Five-year Plan". This data adopts a hierarchical land cover classification system, which divides the country into 6 first-class categories (cultivated land, forest land, grassland, water area, urban and rural areas, industrial and mining areas, residential land and unused land) and 31 second-class categories. This is the most accurate land use data product in our country at present. It has already played an important role in national land resources survey, hydrology and ecological research.
metadata.instructions:
File name: data is stored in vector SHP format, and the file name is "inner mongolia-2000";
Data reading: it can be opened and read by remote sensing software such as ArcGIS and QGIS.

background: Land-use/cover change has become an event being of paramount importance to the study of global environmental change. Land-cover change is closely related to the terrestrial surface material cycles and life-support processes, i.e., the interaction between biosphere and atmosphere, biodiversity, biogeochemical cycle and sustainable exploitation of resources. The series of scientific study programs, issued and promoted by IGBP and IHDP in 1995, make the study of land-use and land-cover change (LUCC) become one of the hot topics in the global environmental change study. As a developing but booming country, China has formulated a series of policies exerting great influence on the land-use change. In addition, due to varied physical environments and vast land areas, its land-use changes not only influence the social and economic development but also impact the global change accordingly.
research objective: In this paper, the division of dynamic regionalization of land-use change is designed, for the sake of revealing the temporal and spatial features of land-use change and laying the foundation for the study of regional scale land-use changes. The paper exerts an effective effort on the integrated studies of “spatial pattern” and “temporal process” for land-use change to reveal the regional land-use change characteristics on the pattern of dynamic process and dynamic process of pattern.
challenges: It is too early to say that the trend of deforestation has been effectively reversed across China. There also exist conspicuous conflicts between arable land protection and urban expansion, as showed in the irrational conversion from arable land to built-up areas.
dataset: The main data sources are Landsat TM digital images (520 scenes in 1995/1996 and 508 scenes in 1999/2000). Apart from that, the CBERS-1 (China-Brazil Earth Resources Satellite 1) data were also used to acquire land-use information for 1999/2000.
findings: There exists conspicuous regional differentiation of land-use change in China, which lays the foundation to draw the dynamic zones. The rapid change of land-use change during 1995—2000 happened in North China, Loess Plateau—agricultural and pasturing interlaced area, Northeast China, southeast coastal region, middle and lower reaches of Yangtze River, eastern coastal region.

background: Land cover plays a significant role in Earth system science, which reflects the influence of human activities and environmental changes. Reliable and up-to-date land cover data are very important for land, ecological and hydrological modelling, carbon and water cycle study as well as global climatic change study. Many land use/cover maps at global, continental, and regional scales have been produced in recent years using remote sensing. These four global land cover maps are all derived from remote sensing data and created for the same fundamental purpose of providing improved land cover information for scientific studies and environmental monitoring, but they are different in mapping methods, data sources, and classification systems.
research objective: The objective of this paper is to evaluate the application of the four popular land cover maps over China land mass. The possibility of developing a new land cover map whose classification is compatible with a well-accepted legend system but whose accuracy is more reliable also motivates this study.
challenges: The four maps used different classification systems, which made the comparison difficult. We conclude that the accuracies of all the datasets cannot meet the requirements of land surface modelling. For the reference data, i.e. the 1:100 000 land cover map, the classification system needs to be transferred to a well-recognized one that has been used commonly in land surface modelling.
methods: We compare and evaluate four land cover datasets over China. So we first aggregated these maps by reclassifying them using a unified legend system. A large-scale, i.e. 1:100 000 land cover map of China was used as the reference data to validate the four maps.
dataset: The datasets include the Version 2 global land cover dataset of IGBP, MODIS land cover map 2001, a global land cover map produced by the University of Maryland, and the land cover map produced by the global land cover for the year 2000 (GLC 2000) project coordinated by the Global Vegetation Monitoring Unit of the European Commission Joint Research Centre. The large-scale (1:100 000) land use map of China in 2000, which was produced by Chinese Academy of Science to meet large-scale resource survey and land use mapping, was used as truth to validate the four land cover maps over China.
findings: The results show that the GLC2000 land cover map represents the highest accuracy. The MODIS land cover map ranks second for type area consistency and third for sub-fraction overall accuracy compared with reference data. The IGBP land cover map has good labelling accuracy, although it has a local labelling error and third consistency for type area. The labelling accuracy and type area consistency for the reference data of UMd land cover map is low.

Definition.Question: What is the significance of using satellite remote sensing in the creation of land-use datasets?
Definition.Answer: Satellite remote sensing is a critical tool for creating land-use datasets as it allows for large-scale data collection over extensive geographical areas. For instance, Landsat MSS, TM, and ETM data are used to construct detailed land-use maps, enabling the classification of land into specific categories like cropland, forest, grassland, water bodies, urban areas, and unused land. This method provides high precision land-use data crucial for national land resource surveys, hydrology, and ecological research.

Definition.Question: What challenges are associated with comparing different land cover datasets?
Definition.Answer: One major challenge in comparing different land cover datasets is the variability in classification systems used by each dataset. This inconsistency makes it difficult to directly compare the data, thereby impacting their applicability in land surface modeling. To address this, datasets often need to be reclassified or aggregated using a unified legend system to facilitate accurate comparison and evaluation.

Comparison.Question: What are the differences in data sources used for land cover change analysis, and how do these sources influence the findings on regional differentiation of land-use change in China?
Comparison.Answer: The data sources for land cover change analysis include Landsat TM digital images and CBERS-1 data for 1999/2000. These sources influence findings by providing distinct temporal snapshots that reveal regional differentiation of land-use change in China, highlighting areas like North China and the Loess Plateau as regions of rapid change during 1995-2000.

Comparison.Question: In what ways do the accuracy and consistency of the MODIS land cover map compare to the GLC2000 map, and how might these differences affect their application in environmental monitoring?
Comparison.Answer: The MODIS land cover map ranks second for type area consistency and third for sub-fraction overall accuracy compared to the GLC2000 map, which has the highest accuracy. These differences can affect their application in environmental monitoring, with GLC2000 being potentially more reliable for accurate representation, while MODIS may require additional calibration or validation efforts.

Interpretation.Question: What implications can be drawn from the use of Landsat TM and CBERS-1 data in understanding regional land-use changes?
Interpretation.Answer: The utilization of Landsat TM and CBERS-1 data suggests a comprehensive approach to capturing land-use changes over time, providing insights into the temporal and spatial features of land-use dynamics. This approach helps in understanding the regional differentiation and rapid changes in land-use patterns, particularly in areas like North China and the Loess Plateau.

Interpretation.Question: How do different classification systems in land cover maps affect the interpretation of land-use data, and what adjustments might be needed for consistency?
Interpretation.Answer: Different classification systems can complicate the comparison and interpretation of land-use data, as they may not align with each other or with the needs of land surface modeling. To improve consistency, it may be necessary to reclassify data using a unified legend system or transfer existing classification systems to more commonly recognized ones for better accuracy and comparability.

Interpretation.Question: What can be inferred about the challenges of balancing urban expansion and arable land protection from the observed patterns of land-use change in China?
Interpretation.Answer: The observed patterns indicate significant conflicts between urban expansion and arable land protection, highlighting challenges in managing land resources effectively. This suggests a need for policies that better balance developmental pressures with the preservation of essential agricultural lands, to prevent irrational land conversions and ensure sustainable land-use management.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What factors contribute to the challenges in achieving high accuracy in land cover classification systems used in large-scale datasets?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The challenges include different classification systems used by various datasets, making comparison difficult. Additionally, the accuracies of all datasets may not meet the requirements of land surface modeling, which suggests a need for a well-recognized classification system commonly used in such modeling.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What are the underlying reasons for the conflicts between arable land protection and urban expansion in China, and how do these conflicts impact data collection methods?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Conflicts between arable land protection and urban expansion arise from the irrational conversion from arable land to built-up areas. These conflicts highlight the need for data collection methods that can accurately capture and reflect the rapid changes in land use, particularly in areas prone to such conflicts.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the potential consequences of utilizing a multi-tiered land cover classification system in the development of large-scale land use datasets?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Utilizing a multi-tiered land cover classification system allows for more detailed and precise categorization of land use types, which can enhance the dataset's accuracy and applicability in national resource surveys, hydrological, and ecological research. This approach supports a deeper understanding of land-use changes and their temporal and spatial dynamics, facilitating more effective policy formulation and environmental monitoring.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the potential impacts of integrating global land cover datasets, such as MODIS or GLC2000, with regional datasets in improving land surface models?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Integrating global land cover datasets with regional datasets can enhance the accuracy and applicability of land surface models by providing a more holistic view of land cover changes. This integration helps overcome limitations associated with individual datasets, such as classification errors or local inconsistencies, and enables a more comprehensive assessment of land-use impacts on ecological and hydrological processes. However, it also requires careful reconciliation of different classification systems and consideration of the specific regional context to ensure meaningful and reliable model outputs.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What procedures could be implemented to enhance the accuracy of land cover classification using satellite imagery in land-use studies?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The use of satellite imagery such as Landsat TM and CBERS-1 data provides foundational land-use information. However, challenges in classification accuracy can be addressed by using a unified legend system for comparison, as seen with the reclassification of the four land cover datasets over China. This approach helps in creating compatibility across different classification systems to improve accuracy for land surface modeling.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: How can remote sensing technologies be employed to detect and analyze temporal changes in land use across large geographical areas?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Remote sensing technologies utilize satellite data like Landsat MSS, TM, and ETM to conduct macro surveys and dynamic research on land use. These technologies help in understanding temporal and spatial features of land-use changes by integrating 'spatial pattern' and 'temporal process' analyses, which can reveal regional characteristics and patterns of dynamic processes.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What methods can be used to validate land cover datasets against reference data to ensure reliability in environmental modeling?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Validation of land cover datasets can be achieved by using a large-scale map, such as the 1:100 000 land cover map of China, as reference data. By aggregating and reclassifying datasets to a unified legend system, the comparison and evaluation of different land cover maps can be performed, ensuring their accuracy and consistency for use in environmental modeling.

Enablement.Question: How do remote sensing technologies enable the creation of reliable land cover maps at various scales for environmental monitoring?
Enablement.Answer: Remote sensing technologies provide data for creating land cover maps at global, continental, and regional scales. These maps are derived from various sources such as MODIS and GLC2000, and serve the fundamental purpose of improving land cover information for scientific studies and environmental monitoring.

Enablement.Question: What conditions or frameworks need to be established to ensure the compatibility and accuracy of land cover classification systems in global datasets?
Enablement.Answer: Establishing a unified legend system and using large-scale reference data, such as the 1:100 000 land cover map of China, ensures compatibility and accuracy in classification systems across global datasets. This approach addresses challenges related to differing classification systems and data accuracy requirements for land surface modeling.

Expectation.Question: Why might there be discrepancies in classification systems between different land cover datasets, and what are the implications for data collection methods?
Expectation.Answer: The four maps used different classification systems, which made the comparison difficult. This suggests that data collection methods may need to adapt their classification systems to ensure compatibility and reliability for land surface modelling.

Expectation.Question: What challenges might be expected when trying to reverse deforestation trends using remote sensing datasets, and how can data collection techniques address these challenges?
Expectation.Answer: It is too early to say that the trend of deforestation has been effectively reversed across China, indicating that current data collection techniques may need to be enhanced to better monitor and address the conflicts between arable land protection and urban expansion.

Expectation.Question: Why might existing land cover datasets not meet the accuracy requirements for land surface modelling, and what improvements in data collection methods could be anticipated to address this?
Expectation.Answer: The accuracies of all the datasets cannot meet the requirements of land surface modelling, suggesting that improvements might include developing a new land cover map with a classification compatible with a well-accepted legend system and increased accuracy.

Judgmental.Question: How would you evaluate the effectiveness of using remote sensing data, such as Landsat and CBERS-1, in capturing detailed land-use changes across diverse regions in China?
Judgmental.Answer: Remote sensing data like Landsat and CBERS-1 are highly effective for capturing detailed land-use changes due to their ability to provide extensive temporal and spatial coverage. They offer valuable insights into regional differentiation of land-use change, especially for periods like 1995-2000 in China, which is crucial for understanding regional scale changes and informing land management policies.

Judgmental.Question: What is your opinion on the challenges faced when comparing different land cover datasets, especially regarding classification system differences and accuracy requirements for land surface modeling?
Judgmental.Answer: The challenges are significant when comparing different land cover datasets due to varied classification systems, which complicates direct comparisons and aggregation efforts. Accuracy remains a critical issue, as shown by the need to use a well-recognized legend system for land surface modeling, indicating that current datasets may not fully meet modeling requirements.

Judgmental.Question: In your view, what are the potential advantages and limitations of using a large-scale land use map, like the 1:100 000 map of China, as a reference for validating global land cover maps?
Judgmental.Answer: Using a large-scale land use map as a reference offers the advantage of high resolution and detail, which can improve validation accuracy. However, limitations include the potential for misalignment in classification systems and the need for adaptation to global datasets' scales and purposes, which might affect comparability and the overall validation process.

Assertion.Question: I don't understand how remote sensing data can be effectively utilized for creating accurate land cover maps.
Assertion.Answer: Remote sensing data from sources like Landsat MSS, TM, ETM, and CBERS-1 are utilized to construct detailed land cover maps by using a hierarchical land cover classification system. This method allows for differentiation into primary classes such as cropland, forest, grassland, and more. The data facilitate the mapping of large areas efficiently and are instrumental in applications like resource survey and land use modeling.

Assertion.Question: I'm unsure about the challenges faced in comparing land cover datasets from different sources.
Assertion.Answer: Challenges in comparing land cover datasets arise primarily due to differences in classification systems used by different datasets, which makes direct comparison difficult. Additionally, the existing datasets have varying levels of accuracy that may not meet the requirements of land surface modeling, necessitating the reclassification of data to a unified legend system for effective comparison.

Assertion.Question: I can't make sense of why there is such significant regional differentiation in land-use change across China.
Assertion.Answer: Significant regional differentiation in land-use change across China can be attributed to varied physical environments and vast land areas, which influence social and economic development differently. Rapid changes have been observed in regions like North China and the Loess Plateau due to their specific agricultural and urbanization dynamics, impacting both local and global environmental changes.

Request/Directive.Question: Please explore and summarize the different data collection techniques used for land-use/cover change studies in China, focusing on the integration of remote sensing technologies like Landsat and CBERS.
Request/Directive.Answer: The data collection techniques for land-use/cover change studies in China have primarily relied on satellite remote sensing technologies. Landsat TM digital images, consisting of multiple scenes from different years, have been a significant source, providing detailed temporal and spatial data. Additionally, the CBERS-1 (China-Brazil Earth Resources Satellite 1) data were utilized to complement the collection, offering broader coverage and enhancing land-use information accuracy for specific periods.

Request/Directive.Question: Please investigate potential strategies for enhancing the accuracy and reliability of land cover maps used in global environmental change studies, particularly within the context of China.
Request/Directive.Answer: Enhancing the accuracy and reliability of land cover maps can be approached by integrating multiple datasets and using advanced remote sensing technologies. Evaluating and comparing existing maps against a reliable reference dataset, such as the large-scale (1:100,000) land use map of China, can help identify discrepancies and improve consistency. Developing a new map that aligns with a recognized classification system and employing cross-validation with high-accuracy datasets, like GLC2000, could further ensure reliability.
